questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with intractable ascites underwent a procedure as shown below. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt(TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device.

The main indication of TIPS is for variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment, and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and superior venacava, a guidewire is inserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The main early complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Shunts for Portal Hypertension:

  • Non- Selective Shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective Shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with regurgitation of food and exacerbated nocturnal cough for a week. He also notices gurgling sounds while swallowing. On barium fluoroscopic examination, the given finding is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis​?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and barium swallow showing a fraction of the ingested barium sulfate being trapped in a pharyngeal pouch in the cervical esophagus suggests a diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum. 

Zenker diverticulum, otherwise known as cricopharyngeal achalasia/pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum (false diverticula occurring due to motor disorder causing increased intraluminal pressure). It results from the herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle (dehiscence of Killian).

Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus (shown below).

 

It is usually seen in the seventh decade of life and is thought to occur due to loss of muscle tone and elasticity causing incomplete relaxation. The impaired relaxation and spasms of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing results in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Patients complain of dysphagia, halitosis, recurrent regurgitation, and respiratory infections. The most serious complications are aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.

Diagnosis is by barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy. The gold standard of treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The transoral endoscopic approach is known as the Dohlman procedure in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size. Lesions less than 2 cm are managed with myotomy. A sac more than 5 cm is usually excised.

Other options:

Option A: Epiphrenic diverticula is a pulsion pseudodiverticula that arises from the terminal third of the thoracic esophagus (next to the diaphragm). They are often associated with diffuse spasm, achalasia, and other esophageal motor abnormalities. 

Option B: Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder and a premalignant condition that occurs due to hypertension of the lower esophageal sphincter and thereby failure to relax. The classic triad of presentation is dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Esophagogram shows the classic bird beak appearance (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). 

Option D: Lateral pharyngeal diverticulum, otherwise known as a pharyngocele, is the herniation of the lateral pharyngeal wall in the piriform recess or vallecula. Patients are often asymptomatic or may complain of dysphagia, neck mass, cervical pain, etc. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts. 

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease undergoes renal transplantation. Six months post-transplant he develops symptoms suggestive of graft dysfunction. Which of the following pathogens can be held principally responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most common cause of infection leading to graft dysfunction is the BK (Polyoma) virus. 

BK Virus:

BK virus is emerging as an important cause of graft dysfunction after renal transplantation. Infection with the BK virus is almost universal during childhood, with latent infection in the epithelium of the urinary tract. Immunosuppression causes lytic BK virus replication with graft involvement in 1–5% of renal transplants. Infection with the polyomavirus BK has been found in association with progressive nephropathy and ureteral obstruction. 

Detection of BK viral DNA in blood and urine has been useful for diagnosis and monitoring response to therapy. BK virus-associated nephropathy is controlled by cidofovir, IV immunoglobulin. 

The only effective treatment is to reduce the level of immunosuppression.

questions.text: As a first year resident you are asked to use the Gridiron incision to perform an open appendectomy. Which of the following incisions will you use?
questions.solution:
The labelled incision '3' is the McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy. Below is the image of various other abdominal incisions.

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favoured in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and the adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique mus-cle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A 26-year-old married woman presented with complaints of difficulty in breast-feeding in the right breast. The appearance of the right breast is shown in the below image. This finding is seen in all of the following conditions except,
questions.solution:
The above image shows a slit-like retraction of the nipple, which is seen in all the given conditions except ductal carcinoma.

A slit-like retraction of the nipple may be caused by duct ectasia, chronic periductal mastitis, and other benign breast conditions like fibroadenoma.

Circumferential retraction of the nipple is suggestive of underlying carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with painless progressive swelling over the past 2 years as shown below. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, the mass is 5-cm firm, movable, there is the displacement of tonsillar pillars and the swelling is variable in consistency. Post-surgery biopsy revealed the epithelial elements to be resembling ductal cells and myoepithelial cells arranged as ducts, acini and sheets of cells. Which of the following statements regarding this tumor is true?

choices.text: Most commonly affects male gender and smokers
Most common salivary gland tumor in adults.
Open biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice
Facial nerve is commonly involved in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma. The only true statement regarding pleomorphic adenoma is that it is the most common salivary gland tumor in adults.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females (Option -A) around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of the deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumour – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Specific features:

  • Slowly growing benign tumour
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumour mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement (Option-D)
  • The deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve and seedling of the tumour (Option-C)

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation). Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion , direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.

Note: Malignant change occurs in about 1.5 to 9.5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

 

Microscopic features:

  • The epithelial elements resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • These epithelial elements are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: While converting a circular incision made for the excision of a skin lesion into an ellipse, what should be the ideal length: width ratio of an elliptical incision for the wound to heal without tension?
questions.solution:
While converting a circular incision made for the excision of a skin lesion into an ellipse, the ratio of length: width ratio of an elliptical incision should be 3:1 for the wound to heal without tension.

This rule of thumb is especially useful when such circular incisions have to be made in regions where the direction of Langer's lines is not apparent. Once the circular incision is made, the wound reveals the lines of tension as the circular incision gets pulled into an ellipse by the tension present. Once the direction becomes evident from this, the circular incision should formally be converted into an ellipse using the above rule of thumb.

If 'dog ears' remain at the ends of an elliptical wound, they should be picked up with a skin hook and excised to obtain a better cosmetic outlook.

questions.text: A woman presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot coffee on her hands. On examination, the following finding was seen on her right hand. The injuries were extremely painful when touched. The capillary refilling time and pinprick sensations were normal. Which degree of burns would this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, normal capillary refilling time, and normal pinprick sensations. The epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis) are involved in this case. These burns will heal without scarring in 2 weeks.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial: Involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched. Sensations are normal. They heal without scarring.
    • Deep: Involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and sensation is reduced. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure. They can lead to hypertrophic scarring.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues as well.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue has a defect of more than 2 cm.  The patient is planned for hemiglossectomy and tongue reconstruction using a radial forearm flap. The surgeon plans to use the following approach. What is this procedure/ approach called?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the visor approach (like the visor of the helmet). It provides excellent access to the floor of the mouth and tongue. 

In the Visor approach, an incision is made in the cervical crease from the mastoid to the mastoid. Another incision is made in the lingual gingival sulcus from one posterior molar to the other side posterior molar. This frees the skin which is present over the chin and floor of the mouth. This flap is elevated like a visor of the helmet providing a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

The lip-split (Option A) and paramedian/ median mandibulotomy approaches are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal cancers. Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most commonly used access procedure. It provides better access to posterior oral cavity, base of tongue, and oropharynx.

Trans-oral wedge resection (Option C) is done for moderate-sized anterior oral tumors.

Commando operation (Option D) is combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection, and it is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: You are an intern asked to catheterize a patient using a 16F Foley's catheter. You are unable to catheterize the patient and decide to use a slightly smaller catheter. The ward sister gives you the following four fresh catheters. Which one would you choose instead?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter having a green coloured ring in the ballon port is of size 14 F. If there is difficulty in catheterization, then a lower French number should be preferred.

The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after being rescued from a burning house where he was trapped for 4 hours. The patient has a few minor burns but is coughing extensively. His voice is hoarse and he is able to drink water with some difficulty. What is the safest strategy of management?

choices.text: O2 therapy with well-fitting face mask

questions.solution:
For a patient who presents with a history or suspicion of inhalational burn injury, elective endotracheal intubation is the safest strategy.

Delay can make intubation very difficult because of airway edema and can lead to airway obstruction. One should be ready to perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy if intubation is delayed.

Recognition of the potentially burned airway:

  • A history of being trapped in the presence of smoke or hot gases
  • Burns on the palate or nasal mucosa, or loss of all the hairs in the nose
  • Deep burns around the mouth and neck

American Burn Life Support (ABLS) indications for early intubation include:

  • Signs of airway obstruction (hoarseness, stridor, accessory respiratory muscle use, sternal retraction)
  • The extent of the burn (TBSA > 40%–50%)
  • Extensive and deep facial burns
  • Burns inside the mouth or difficulty swallowing
  • Significant edema or risk for edema
  • Signs of respiratory compromise: Inability to clear secretions, respiratory fatigue, poor oxygenation or ventilation
  • Decreased level of consciousness where airway protective reflexes are impaired
  • Anticipated patient transfer of large burn with airway issue without qualified personnel to intubate en route

questions.text: A 37-year-old man who works on a cattle farm presented with right upper quadrant pain and intermittent low-grade fever for the past 2 weeks. On examination, he is febrile and has mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant. CT scan revealed the following findings. Which of the following findings if present would form an indication for the choice of PAIR ( puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration) procedure?
questions.solution:
The case scenario with the CT scan showing a 'water lily sign' is suggestive of a hydatid cyst  and PAIR procedure is indicated in infected cysts. 

Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts. The hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called the pericyst that is derived from the host tissue. The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts.

The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

The image below shows the cross section of the hydatid cyst.

The first/initial imaging test is USG, and a CT scan can be used to diagnose the condition. CT scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. 
The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.

Management:

Asymptomatic and inactive cysts are managed conservatively and monitored by ultrasound. Active cysts should first be treated by a full course of albendazole. Procedures used for treatment include PAIR, pericystectomy, and laparoscopic marsupialization of the cyst.

PAIR is a minimally invasive technique that complements or replaces surgical treatment. It is done after adequate drug treatment with albendazole or praziquantel. It involves puncture, aspiration of the cystic fluid, injection of 95% ethanol solution or hypertonic saline, and re-aspiration of the solution after 5 minutes. Puncture is done under ultrasound guidance.

 

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues. Which of the following investigations will confirm the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis,  which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy.

FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.

Riedel’s thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue. It is an IgG4-related systemic disease characterized by:

  • Elevated serum IgG4 levels
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
  • Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cells

It is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal, periorbital, retro-orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis.

Clinical features:

  • Occurs predominantly in women between 30-60 years
  • Painless, hard anterior neck mass
  • Progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression:
    • Dysphagia
    • Dyspnea
    • Choking
    • Hoarseness
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue
  • Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues

Treatment includes surgery, high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.

questions.text: If you were to prevent the development of surgical site infection in your patient posted for left hemicolectomy, which of the following would you not do against the surgical care improvement project performance measure guidelines?

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with recurrent epigastric pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. On investigation, his serum protein level was found to be low. An endoscopy was done, and an image obtained when the scope was in the stomach is shown below. The gastric aspirate showed a decrease in the acid content of the stomach. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds, which are characteristic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.

This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells. The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds. The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.

Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.

Some patients may respond to cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR). Severe cases require a gastrectomy.

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (option C) shows the presence of parallel red stripes over the gastric mucosa (watermelon stomach).

questions.text: A young man with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is posted for splenectomy. His platelet count is 32000 per cubic millimeter. What is the best time to transfuse platelets in this patient?

choices.text: Immediately after the ligation of splenic artery
Immediately after the ligation of splenic vein

questions.solution:
The best time to transfuse platelets in this patient is immediately after ligation of the splenic artery.

The platelets are destroyed by the spleen within one hour of transfusion, and the splenic artery is the major vessel that brings blood to the spleen. Therefore, the best time to transfuse the platelets is immediately after the ligation of the splenic artery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: Mr. Raju, a 54-year-old male, complains of on and off difficulty in swallowing food. On performing an endoscopy the following finding is noted. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of a Schatzki’s ring in the lower end of the esophagus.

Schtazki’s ring is a circumferential ring present in the lower end of the esophagus near the squamocolumnar junction. The patients usually present with intermittent dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

Barium swallow and endoscopy will show the presence of a single ring in the distal portion of the esophagus.

Other options:

Eosinophilic esophagitis (option A) shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus.This appearance is called as the feline esophagus or ringed esophagus.

Esophageal web (option C) appears as a thin membrane. It can occur alone or as a part of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Esophageal leiomyoma (option D) appears as an oval intramural mass arising from the wall of the esophagus.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. During the procedure, while fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Injury to which of the following nerves has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP repair- Transabdominal preperitoneal repair
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh lies in the anatomical landmark known as the triangle of pain (as described in the pearl) and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair. 


In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

questions.text: Mrs Sucharitra Tiwari, a dynamic businesswoman, CEO of a company is your patient who is posted for metabolic surgery. She is suffering from obesity which she feels is affecting her self-confidence and output in terms of a business magnet. She wishes to get a reduction surgery done. She is 47-years-old with a BMI of 38kg/m2. Her RBS value is 186 mg/dl and her BP measurement records a value of 120/78 mm of Hg. Which of the following factors would you take into consideration and give a score of one while discussing on the lines of Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) regarding the prognosis of her condition?

questions.text: A 29-year-old man who has come for his annual health checkup is found to have the following finding in the chest x-ray. His clinical examination is quite unremarkable and his abdomen is soft. You probe him regarding any significant symptoms and he responds that he has no complaints and has come only because the health check was free. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows pseudopneumoperitoneum which is seen in Chilaiditi’s syndrome. 

It is the harmless and asymptomatic interposition of the large bowel between the liver and diaphragm. It has to be differentiated from pneumoperitoneum because it does not require any intervention.

Features that suggest a Chilaiditi syndrome are:

  • The gas between the liver and diaphragm.
  • Rugal folds within the gas suggesting that it is within the bowel and not free.

Other options:

Pneumoperitoneum (option A) appears as subdiaphragmatic free gas.

Pneumopericardium (option B) appears as a dark line around the heart. (Indicated by the solid white arrow.)

questions.text:
You are attending your final university practical examination. In the Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE) station, you are asked to look at the image shown in the flashcard (attached below) and identify the incorrect statement regarding the procedure/test. What would your answers be?
  1. The flashcard displays Carnett's test
  2. It helps differentiate intra-peritoneal from the retroperitoneal mass.
  3. It can differentiate intra-abdominal from parietal swelling.
  4. If the swelling becomes more prominent with this test, it indicates a parietal swelling. 
  5. It is helpful in ruling out psychogenic abdominal pain
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Carnett's test / Leg rising test. 

It helps differentiate intra-peritoneal from the retroperitoneal mass is the incorrect statement. To differentiate intra-peritoneal from retroperitoneal types of intra-abdominal mass, the examination is preferred in the knee-elbow position. 

Carnett's test:

  • It is done specifically in cases of lower abdominal swellings.
  • This can differentiate intra-abdominal from parietal swelling.
  • The patient is asked to lie supine and is asked to lift both legs from the bed.
  • If the swelling disappears or becomes less prominent, then the swelling is intra-abdominal. On the contrary, if the swelling becomes more prominent it is suggestive of a parietal swelling. 
  • With this test, the parietal swelling is fixed to the abdominal muscle, then it becomes less mobile
  • The principle behind the test is to make the abdominal muscles contract to reveal the location of the swelling.
  • Helpful in ruling out psychogenic pelvic pain and chronic abdominal pain syndrome

Note:

To differentiate intra-peritoneal from retroperitoneal types of intra-abdominal mass, the examination is preferred in the knee-elbow position. This being a very inconvenient position for the patient, this test is generally avoided. This test can also detect very minimal free fluid in the abdomen and a positive collection of fluid near the umbilicus is called a puddle's sign.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Psychological re-evaluation is necessary to address the underlying psychological blocks in a patient who is unable to comply with the diet.

Morbidly obese individuals, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make surgery impossible. Liver shrinkage diet helps reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure.  

Liver shrinkage diet:

  • Low-carbohydrate, low-fat and moderate protein diet
  • Started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery

The ability to comply with the diet and lose weight suggests that the patient is willing to make an effort to adopt lifestyle modifications. Failure to do so must arouse suspicion of important underlying psychological blocks, which need addressing.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of a neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck, as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing mass in the posterior triangle of the neck which is fluctuant and brightly transilluminant is suggestive of cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not a treatment option for cystic hygroma. It is the surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst and limb reduction surgeries in patients with lymphedema.

Cystic hygroma/cavernous lymphangioma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development.

Clinically, it presents as a mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. On examination, it appears as a soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant since the sac is filled with lymph.

Complications of cystic hygroma include respiratory difficulty, secondary infection, and chylothorax.

Management:

  • Primarily, the treatment includes aspiration (Option B) of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.
  • Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy (Option C). Commonly used sclerosants include OK– 432 which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon α 2a, and doxycycline.
  • Multiple cysts are treated by complete excision of the cyst (Option D).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic pancreatitis was referred to a surgeon who plans to perform the following procedure on him. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition. It consists of distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Chronic pancreatitis is associated with multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

The etiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The diagnosis can be made using Rosemont criteria. It is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. It is explained in the pearl attached below. 

Treatment:

Resection or hybrid surgical procedures as attached in the pearl below. 

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)

questions.text: A surgeon uses the given instrument to visualize the lower alimentary tract for tumors in an elderly male. What structures can he visualize?
questions.solution:
The anal canal and lower rectum can be visualised.

A conventional proctoscope can visualize a lesion up to 10-15 cm from the anal verge.

A surgeon uses a lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. It is done as an OPD procedure to detect haemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers. A biopsy may be taken if it is above the anoderm. It is avoided in anal fissures as it causes undue pain.

questions.text: A 25-year-old teacher suffered from a road traffic accident and was brought to the emergency room by people near the accident spot. He opens his eyes to verbal commands and utters incomprehensible sounds. On striking his arms with a sharp-pointed object, he primarily withdraws his hands and scratches to delimit the area stroked by the resident.  His left pupil is unreactive to light while his right pupil reacts to direct light reflex. What is his GCS-P score?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score based on the given clinical scenario is 9 (E3 V2 M5 P1).

It is calculated as follows

  • E: Opening of the eyes to verbal command - 3
  • V: Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • M: Localizes to the pain - Delimits and scratches the area struck by the sharp object - 5
  • P: One pupil does not react to light - 1
  • Total: 3+2+5-1= 9

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Note:

In the case of the scoring components, one must always choose the best performance elicited, so a patient flexing or withdrawing in response to a painful stimulus would constitute a score of 4 but the best performance elicited is that he tries to localize to the pain. Thus, the motor component would get a score of 5. 

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to lower midbrain and upper pons
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the Glasgow Coma Scale.

  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below. Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel obstruction. 

In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from herniating. 

Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly reduces the risk of internal hernia.

Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:

  • Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12      
  • Anastomosis site leak      
  • Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy   
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Marginal ulcers
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak.

Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion.

Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Tillaux sign?

choices.text: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line

questions.solution:
Tillaux's sign is said to be positive if the mass/swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Tillaux’s sign is seen in a mesenteric cyst.

Mesenteric cysts occur either in the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following:

  • Chylolymphatic (most common type)
  • Enterogenous
  • Urogenital remnant
  • Dermoid
  • Other causes: traumatic hematoma and cyst formation, tuberculous cold abscess of mesentery and hydatid cyst of the mesentery

They most commonly occur in adults with a mean age of 45 years. It is more common in females than males (2:1). The most common presentation is a painless abdominal swelling near the umbilicus, which is smooth and not moving with respiration with Tillaux's triad: 

  • Soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region
  • Freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to the mesentery (Tillaux's sign)
  • Zone of resonance around the cyst 

Other presentations include recurrent attacks of abdominal pain due to temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of the bowel narrowed by the cyst and vomiting.

Complications of mesenteric cyst include torsion, rupture, infection and hemorrhage into the cyst. 

Ultrasonography and CT are used to demonstrate mesenteric cysts.

Treatment:

  • Chlyolymphatic cyst is managed by enucleation.
  • Enterogenous cyst is managed by removal of the cyst with resection of the adjacent bowel as it arises as a diverticulum or duplication from the adjacent bowel. 

In cases where complete excision is not possible due to the close proximity to vital structures, partial excision or marsupialization should be performed.

questions.text: A woman presents with a high fever, vomiting, and one episode of seizures. She appears confused. She is a known case of Graves' disease with medication non-compliance.  For the past few days, she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. On examination, she has warm, moist skin, and tremors. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. Which of the following is not part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves' disease and an acute infection, now presents with high-grade fever, vomiting, one episode of seizure, and confusion. This is suggestive of a thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crisis. Management will not include Liothyronine. The patient is already in a state of thyrotoxicosis, in such cases, the addition of the most active form of thyroid hormone will be detrimental.

L3/ Liothyronine has a rapid onset of action and is indicated only in conditions where rapid action is preferred like rare cases of myxedema coma.

A thyroid storm is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. It is an acute hypermetabolic state induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones. Crisis can be due to surgical or medical causes.

Causes:

  • Thyroidectomy
  • Stress
  • Infection
  • Trauma
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Emergency surgery
  • Drugs like anticholinergics or antiadrenergic or NSAIDs or chemotherapy

Features: They present 12–24 hours after surgery, but can occur on the table also.

  • General: Hyperpyrexia (> 41°C), severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • Respiratory: Tachypnoea, hyperventilation
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 
  • Bailey’s symptom complex of thyroid storm is – insomnia, anorexia, diarrhoea, vomiting, sweating, emotional instability, fever, tachycardia, aggravated toxic features, multiorgan dysfunction.

Differential diagnoses are—malignant hyperpyrexia, septic shock, anxious status, cardiac disorders.

Investigations:

  • Raised T3, T4, suppressed TSH
  • Raised serum calcium
  • ECG and echocardiography show arrhythmias 
  • Raised total count
  • Altered liver function tests
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows acid-base imbalance 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures –
    • rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
    • Antipyretics like a paracetamol IV infusion
    • Glucocorticoids (Hydrocortisone 500 mg IV or dexamethasone injections)
    • IV dextrose infusion as there is more metabolic demand
    • Correction of electrolytes
    • Treating cardiac arrhythmias in the ICU care with ventilator support.
    • Central line, CVP monitor, nasogastric tube, the urinary catheter should be placed.
  • Antiadrenergic drugs – Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. If propranolol is contraindicated, atenolol or metoprolol can be used
  • Thionamides – propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole is used.
  • Iodide compounds – Lugol’s iodide or potassium iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Bile acid suppressants to prevent reabsorption of thyroid hormone from the gut – cholestyramine. Iodinated radiocontrast dyes like iopanoic acid is also beneficial. Lithium carbonate 300 mg 6th hourly is also useful.
  • Digitoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.
  • Treating specific causes 
  • Other measures—Hemodialysis, plasmapheresis, exchange transfusion, charcoal plasma perfusion are other methods used to control the storm.

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress

    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery

  • Acute iodine load

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thyroglossal cyst is the only midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid. 

Thyroglossal duct cyst:

It is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. 

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant.
  • Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in the normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).
Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:
  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: Dhrithi Shah, a 24-year-old young married nullipara woman presents to the OPD with complaints of vague abdominal pain with distension and alternating constipation and diarrhoea. She also gives a history of weight loss, chronic cough, malaise, evening rise in temperature with sweating. She also adds that she is extremely worried and stressed that they have no children despite one year of their marriage. Abdominal examination reveals doughy consistency. She is subjected to a CT scan whose image is attached below. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis and management of this patient is not true?

choices.text: You should investigate her for infertility
Start antitubercular therapy and get a physician opinion
Perforation is treated by appropriate local resection and  anastomosis
The given CT scan depicts string sign

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the CT scan of the patient depicting the cocoon sign is suggestive of abdominal tuberculosis/ intestinal tuberculosis.  Cocoon sign depicts the localised areas of ascites due to sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis that occur in the form of cocoons. Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis/ string sign seen in barium GI studies. 

Intestinal TB:

Infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis is common in the tropics. The increased prevalence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection worldwide has also made tuberculosis more common.

Pathology:

  • Increasingly being seen in non-endemic areas, mostly among immigrants from endemic areas
  • Two types are recognised – ulcerative and hyperplastic
  • The ulcerative type occurs when the virulence of the organism is greater than the host defence
  • The opposite occurs in the hyperplastic type
  • Small bowel strictures are common in the hyperplastic type, mainly affecting the ileocaecal area and presenting with obstructive symptoms
  • In the ulcerative type, the bowel serosa is studded with tubercles
  • Localised areas of ascites occur in the form of cocoons
  • The lungs and other organs, particularly of the genitourinary system, may also be involved simultaneously

Clinical features:

  • Intestinal tuberculosis should be suspected in any patient from an endemic area who presents with weight loss, malaise, evening fever, cough, alternating constipation and diarrhoea and intermittent abdominal pain with distension
  • The abdomen has a doughy feel; a mass may be found in the right iliac fossa
  • The emergency patient presents with features of distal small bowel obstruction – abdominal pain, distension, bilious and feculent vomiting
  • Peritonitis from a perforated tuberculous ulcer in the small bowel can be another emergency presentation

Investigations:

  • Raised inflammatory markers, anaemia and positive sputum culture
  • Interferon-γ release assays for subclinical infection
  • Ultrasound of the abdomen may show localised areas of ascites
  • Chest radiograph shows pulmonary infiltration
  • Barium meal and follow-through shows multiple small bowel strictures particularly in the ileum, with a subhepatic caecum
  • If symptoms warrant, the genitourinary tract is also investigated. These specific investigations would include urine for microscopy and culture; the finding of sterile pyuria should alert the clinician to the possibility of tuberculosis of the urinary tract when the appropriate investigations should be done.
  • A flexible cystoscopy would be very useful in the presence of sterile pyuria.
  • A contracted bladder (‘thimble’ bladder) with ureteric orifices that are in-drawn. A ‘golf hole ureter may be seen; these changes are due to fibrosis.

Signs of tuberculosis of the intestine on Barium studies:

  • String sign
  • Gooseneck sign
  • Sterlein sign
  • Fleishner
  • Pulled-up cecum

Treatment:

  • Patients should ideally be under the combined care of a physician and surgeon
  • Vigorous supportive and full drug treatment are mandatory in all cases
  • Symptomatic strictures are treated by the appropriate resection, e.g. local ileocolic resection or strictureplasty as an elective procedure once the disease is completely under control
  • Acute intestinal obstruction from distal ileal stricture is treated by thorough resuscitation followed by side-to-side intertransverse bypass
  • Once the patient has recovered with medical treatment, then the second-stage definitive procedure of right hemicolectomy is done to remove the blind loop
  • One-stage resection and anastomosis can be considered if the patient’s general condition permits
  • Perforation is treated by appropriate local resection and anastomosis or exteriorisation if the condition of the patient is very poor; this is later followed by restoration of bowel continuity after the patient has fully recovered with antituberculous chemotherapy

The given image depicts the string sign.

 

Infertility is the most common symptom of genital tuberculosis. It can also cause other symptoms such as dyspareunia, menstrual irregularities and lower abdominal pain associated with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.

Genital Tuberculosis:

  • Almost always a secondary infection.
  • The most common route of spread is hematogenous.
  • The most common site is bilateral fallopian tubes (the most common part affected is the ampulla and the most common pathology encountered is endosalpingitis).
  • Most common in 20-30 years age group.
  • Infertility is the most common symptom.

Owing to all these the patient should definitely be evaluated for infertility. 

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: A patient visits your clinic for follow-up after a breast surgery. She undergoes an x-ray scan, the findings of which are given below. Which of the following complications, if present in this patient, would show the linguine sign on MRI?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows silicone breast implants in a patient. MRI showing the linguine sign in post-silicone breast implant patients indicates intra-capsular silicone rupture.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the linguine sign. It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

Intracapsular rupture on MRI.

Breast implants are technically simple and it facilitates achieving symmetry. The implant in submuscular plane is better whenever a muscle is not removed during surgery. If the muscle is removed as in radical mastectomy, then a subcutaneous implant is placed. Silicone gel implants are used.

Complications may include pain, exposure of implant and rupture, infection, calcifications, displacements, intracapsular or extracapsular rupture and silicone granulomas.

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of conservative breast surgery  
  • To assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer 
  • It is the best imaging modality for women with breasts implants
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women with a positive family history.

Generally, ultrasound(USG) is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. (Option-B)

Other options:

Option B: In the case of extracapsular rupture of the silicone implant, it is detected by snowstorm appearance on USG.

Option C: Risk of anaplastic large cell lymphoma of scar tissue is increased in breast implant patients. This is confirmed by biopsy.

Option D: Calcifications in post-implant surgery patients can be detected on X-ray film. MRI used to detect contractures.

questions.text: A young male patient came to the clinic with pigmentation of the mouth as shown in the image below. He also complained of recurrent abdominal pain. After a detailed evaluation, multiple hamartomatous polyps were found in the jejunum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Peutz Jegher's syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter. Female patients are encouraged to attend breast and cervical screening.

Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp. If surgery is done for these indications, attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 

Other options:

Turcot syndrome (option A) is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Lynch syndrome (option B) is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair of DNA.

Cowden disease (option C) is characterized by polyps of the colon or stomach with mucocutaneous lesions, thyroid adenomas and goiter, fibroadenomas and fibrocystic disease of the breast, and uterine leiomyomas.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: You notice the senior resident in the surgery outpatient department advising a patient to use the following treatment option for his condition. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows elastic compression stockings. Among the given options, varicose veins is the condition the patient is most likely to have. 

Elastic compression stockings are commonly prescribed for the treatment of chronic venous insufficiency manifesting as venous ulcers or varicose veins. The principal cause of venous insufficiency is venous hypertension. This venous hypertension can be decreased by compression stockings. It helps to push the blood from superficial engorged veins into the deep veins, thus improving the blood-pumping function of the calf muscle. Hence, it decreases edema and improves tissue oxygenation. 

Complications of this therapy include skin excoriation, dryness, skin maceration, and infection. 

Varicose veins are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb. Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound (IVUS). 

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and open surgery.

Other options-

Option A: Raynaud's disease refers to an abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood. Compression will have no effect on these symptoms. Protection from cold can help. 

Option B: Diabetic foot also occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy and atherosclerosis of small arteries in the legs and feet. Hence, improving venous circulation with compression stockings will have no benefit in this condition. 

Option C: Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans involves occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. It occurs in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. It is an arterial occlusive disorder, so compression stockings will have no therapeutic effect.
