questions.text: A young woman is found to have the following finding during the abdominal CT scan. She has no specific symptoms and this was an incidental finding on her imaging. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It has a risk of malignant transformation
Asymptomatic patients do not require any surgical intervention
FNH always has a true capsule
This is the most common liver lesion

questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the presence of a hypervascular liver lesion with a central non-enhancing scar. This is most likely to be focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

FNH is a benign tumor of the liver which is commonly seen in young women. The exact cause is unknown. 

The patients are usually asymptomatic and the tumor is found incidentally during the imaging studies or laparotomy. A contrast-enhanced CT image shows a hypervascular lesion with a central scar. FNH lacks a true capsule

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation and therefore asymptomatic patients do not require any surgical intervention. Surgical resection can be indicated if the patients have symptoms.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain.  A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the given statements regarding the patient's likely condition is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is more obtuse (>100)
This condition is also called as Wilkie’s syndrome

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta is more acute (<20 degrees).

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

The given image shows compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this disease?

choices.text: MRI is the gold standard modality of investigation
Seton's technique induces fibrosis and  has very good evidence of healing
Sphincter division can lead on to sphincter dysfunction and incontinence
Laying open fistulotomy shows improvement but does not eradicate the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the definitive management method to eradicate the disease. 

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms include perianal pain and intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause the persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

 

Option B: Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. If there is evidence of good healing it is removed.

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loosely placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helps in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

Option C: Laying open is the surest method of eradication, but sphincter division may result in incontinence due to sphincter dysfunction.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency room with nausea,  vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to the usual doses of analgesics. The pain typically radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination. All of the following is used for assessing the severity of the given condition except
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the Grey Turner sign (A) and Cullen's sign (B) shown in the picture, is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above criteria can be used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis except Rosemont’s criteria.

Rosemont’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. 

Revised Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of acute pancreatitis.

Atlanta classification:

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or
  • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours)–single organ or multiorgan

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A 30-year-old teacher underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures?

choices.text: Buccal branch of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Lower lip paralysis occurs when there is an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve. 

Branches of the facial nerve are:

  • Temporal
  • Zygomatic
  • Buccal
  • Marginal mandibular
  • Cervical

The facial nerve passes through the parotid gland, hence it might be injured during parotidectomy.

In contrast to this, the upper lip is supplied by buccal branches of the facial nerve.

Complications of parotidectomy include hematoma formation, infection, deformity (unsightly scarring and retromandibular hollowing), temporary/permanent facial weakness, sialocele, facial numbness, permanent numbness of the earlobe due to great auricular nerve transection and Frey's syndrome.

questions.text: A female patient with fatigue and weight loss had the following upper gastrointestinal endoscopy findings. She was diagnosed with gastric carcinoma involving the mucosa and submucosa without lymph node involvement. Which of the following features of the tumor would not favor an endoscopic resection for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of early gastric cancer. Early gastric cancer having ulceration would not favour performing endoscopic mucosal resection.

The general guidelines for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer are as follows:

  • Tumour smaller than 2 cm
  • Tumour limited to the mucosa
  • No lymphovascular invasion
  • No ulceration
  • Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology

If any of these is not fulfilled, gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

Gastric carcinoma can be classified as early gastric cancer and advanced gastric cancer.

  • Early gastric cancer involves mucosa, submucosa with or without lymph node involvement. Early gastric cancer can be further classified using the Japanese classification.
  • Advanced gastric cancer involves the muscularis layer, with or without adjacent structures. Its macroscopic appearances have been classified using Bormann classification.

The given image shows the pathological types of early gastric cancer as per Japanese system.

The other classifications and risk factors for the development of gastric carcinoma are enlisted in the pearls attached below.

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial

    • Blood group A

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.solution:
The image shows a leukoreduction filter which is used for filtering out donor WBCs. This helps in reducing the incidence of transfusion-related reactions by removing WBC microaggregates. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before the storage of blood.

Potential benefits include reduced risk of: 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients & preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Note: CMV also has an affinity for monocytes and macrophages (types of WBCs). Reduction in WBCs is the cause for the decrease in CMV transmission (accidental benefit), and thus, the main purpose of a leukoreduction filter is not the prevention of CMV transmission (options A and C).

Possible reduced risk of:

  • Transfusion-associated graft versus host disease (TA- GVHD) 
  • Transfusion-related immuno-modulatory (TRIM) effects
  • Transmitting variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease

Other Methods of Leucodepletion are:

  • Specific leucodepletion filters (Most Efficient)
  • Washing
  • Freezing
  • Buffy coat removal
  • Micro-aggregate filtration
  • Low leucocyte apheresis devices

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a subcuticular suture.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either an absorbable or non-absorbable suture material can be used.

Frequently used suture techniques are as follows:

Interrupted suture (Option B): Here, the needle is inserted perpendicular to the incision. It then passes through both sides of the suture line and exits again at a right angle. The distance from the needle's entry point to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured. The next suture should be placed twice the distance away from the first suture (2x). Interrupted sutures are shown below.

 

Continuous suture (Option C): The first suture is placed in the same way as an interrupted suture, but the remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound. It is shown below.

 

Mattress suture (Option D): Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal. They result in either eversion or inversion of the wound edge. The first suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture. After that, the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, who was diagnosed with a ventral hernia, is planned for mesh hernioplasty. The mesh is considered to be well placed if it covers all margins of the defect by a distance at least ________.
questions.solution:
The mesh should cover all the margins of the defect by at least 20 mm (2 cm) for it to be considered as a well-placed mesh. A well-placed mesh should have good overlap around all the margins of the defect by at least 2 cm and up to 5 cm if possible.

Mesh hernioplasty involves placing a tension-free prosthetic mesh over the hernia defect. It also strengthens the hernia repair after the defect is closed with sutures. Sometimes, a 3-dimensional mesh is kept in the defect to prevent future herniation through the defect. 

The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.

Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.

Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltration, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less than other meshes. This results in fewer adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and less patient discomfort and pain than that observed with other meshes. 

Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological mesh depending on their composition.

Synthetic meshes are more commonly used these days. They are made from polymers of polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). 

Polypropylene Polyester PTFE
Monofilament multifilament solid
Hydrophobic hydrophilic hydrophobic
Rigidity elastic rigid

PTFE meshes are hydrophobic and have a higher risk of adhesion compared to polyester meshes.

Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have fewer complications than other meshes. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength, and hence, their use is restricted to infected environments. 

Note: Microporous meshes (e.g, ePTFE) and multifilament meshes are at higher risk of infection because macrophages and neutrophils are unable to enter small pores (< 10 μm). This allows bacteria (< 1 μm) to survive unchallenged within the pores and braids.
